story:
In memory of my Dad, William, who has recently passed away following a short, and devastating battle with lung cancer. 

Macmillian Cancer Support have been with him, and us, every step of the way. When he got his diagnosis; when he needed to sort out his finances and legal affairs; when he moved in with us and needed increasing care in the final weeks of his life. They have been nothing short of remarkable and this is a way in which we can say thanks and help them to help others who are living with cancer.

With the way the world is right now, we are not going to get the funeral that Dad deserves right now and many people who knew him will be unable to attend to pay their respects. We will get the chance to properly recognise his achievements and celebrate his life in the future when restrictions are eased in the future. Please donate here in lieu of flowers to the family and help us do what he loved doing - look after everyone else.

Mum, Richard, Kelly, Al, and I really appreciate your support at this time and allow us to feel like we're doing something positive.

story:
Kier Group has selected the British Heart Foundation, the biggest independent funder of cardiovascular research in the UK, as its new corporate charity partner. The two-year partnership will help in the charitys aim of increasing awareness of cardiovascular disease, raise £250,000 for vital research in to heart and circulatory conditions as well as train 1,500 Kier colleagues in the lifesaving first aid, CPR.

The British Heart Foundation is funding life saving research to help end heartbreak for the seven million people in the UK living with cardiovascular disease. For over 50 years it has pioneered research that has transformed the lives of people living with heart and circulatory conditions and has been pivotal to offering vital treatments that are changing the fight against heart disease.

story:
We are excited to inform you that in December, we are going to be taking part in the British Heart Foundation’s Christmas fundraising initiative, ‘The BHF Elf Kick’!

We know that there has never been a more important time for children to get moving and focus on their health and wellbeing, recent studies show that 1 in 3 children leaving primary school will already be overweight or living with obesity. 2020 has been a very difficult year for teachers and pupils, so here at the British Heart Foundation (BHF) wehave created a brand new initiative that will allow children to get ‘fit and elfy’ this Christmas, have some festive fun in a completely covid friendly way and all whilst raising funds for the BHF’s lifesaving research. 

What is the BHF Elf Kick? Elf Kick is a series of 12 fitness and wellbeing challenges that the school will take part in, over 12 consecutive days in December. The exercises are all Christmas themed and last no longer than 10 minutes each. They have been designed this way so that we can fit them into any point of the school day! No equipment will be required, and all challenges are suitable to allow for social distancing. 

Where does the fundraising come in? Children will aim to raise as much sponsorship as possible for taking on the Elf Kick challenge! We will provide each child with a sponsorship form. If every pupil raised just £10 each, this would mean that the BHF can go on to fund more machines that can restart hearts, it would give them the ability to fix arteries in tiny babies and the power to give someone a heart they weren’t born with.

The coronavirus pandemic is the biggest challenge the BHF has faced in its 60-year history. All 750 BHF shops were forced to close and dozens of fundraising events remain cancelled. The BHF has been losing over £10 million a month and devastatingly, they may need to cut their research budget in half this year. Heart and circulatory diseases remain the world’s biggest killers affecting millions of people worldwide. They don’t disappear because of a global pandemic. They continue to cause heartbreak on a devastating scale and that is why we are very proud to be supporting the BHF this Christmas by taking part in their Elf Kick Challenge.

Starting on Monday, November 9th, #TouchMyHeart will see England Touch put out one activity challenge and one Touch skills challenge each day for four weeks. Individuals can then choose whichever one they do – or both! – and then tag in their club and friends to show that they have completed it.

Thank you for visiting our page.

2020 has been a difficult year, so Stanway Fiveways wanted to support BHF to create a brand new initiative that allows children to get 'fit and elfy' this Christmas.

What is the BHF Elf Kick?

Elf Kick is a series of 12 fitness and wellbeing challenges that the whole school from EYFS-Year 6 will be taking part in. The exercises will take place over 12 consecutive days, beginning on the 1st December. The exercises are all Christmas themed, suitable for social distancing and last no longer than 10 minutes.

Why are Stanway Fiveways are supporting the BHF?

COVID-19 has cut BHF research in half, slowing down now puts even more lives at risk. At Stanway Fiveways we believe in keeping your heart and mind healthy. We enjoy exercising, Christmas and love to take on a challenge. By completing the 12 challenges in December and with your support we can help BHF continue their amazing work!

Where does my money go?

To help keep safe, we have set this Just Giving page up so the money you pay goes directly to The British Heart Foundation.

Keeping you posted!

Look out for regular updates and posts to see how we are getting on!

Don't forget to let others know what Stanway Fiveways are doing and help spread the word! Thank you!

story:
🎗Please share to raise awareness🎗

On Thursday 20th of August 2020 our whole world came crashing down.

Because of Covid, James couldn’t come to the 12th week scan with me so I thought in treating him to an extra scan as he was looking forward to know baby’s gender and also for him to get to see baby.

We had a private 16th week scan and were told our baby had a ‘lemon shaped head and a banana cerebellum’ and also what  it looks like baby has an abnormality on his spine. We got sent up to Jessops (Sheffield) straight away but they didn’t recheck me. Instead they left us alone with our thoughts for what it was the longest weekend of our lives. But at that point they were telling us the best thing we could do for our baby was to terminate the pregnancy as baby was going to be severely impaired.

We googled, lots of stuff, Arnold Chiari malformation, spina bifida, life expectancy... they were all dreadful news. We were soul and mentally destroyed.

On Monday we went to the Fetal Medicine Unit and I was walked on my own to a small private room. A counselling room. They confirmed by scan that our baby had spina bifida, the most severe form, a myelomeningocele. It was also confirmed our baby had a brain malformation as consequence of this, Arnold Chiari type II.

By then, we already read lots and we came across the MOM’s study in USA and we also knew there was the option of a prenatal surgery. We didn’t know if we were suitable but after checking UCLH guidelines we knew we were pretty close to be.

In Jessops, we were given 2 choices,, to terminate the pregnancy or carry on with the possibility of terminate at any stage.We knew that we actually had 3 choices so we pushed for the prenatal surgery.

That day, I got an amniocentesis to discard there weren’t any other chromosomical problems with our baby and an MRI programmed around 20/40w of pregnancy.

We weren’t given more information, no leaflets, nothing else than a telephone number and the promise there would be somebody at the end of the phone for us if we change our mind or we needed to talk to anyone.

We continued our research and kept reading about the difference this surgery was making in babies in the USA and how there were other couples who have had this surgery in the U.K.

This surgery is a complex surgery, they opened mum’s abdomen and expose uterus and unborn baby and repair baby’s NTD in situ. It has incredibly benefits in baby’s prognosis of walking and also with the Arnold Chiari malformation and it also reduces the chances of baby needing a shunt later on in life. If this surgery gets done before the 26 weeks landmark, it prevents the amniotic fluid to further damage baby’s nerves and therefore preserves most of its functionality. 

I also came across SHINE, who were really helpful and our our mind at ease and also I found Elouise’ mum blog regarding her own experience. I felt so identified that I bursted into tears and after few days I gained some strength to message her to say thank you, thank you for her page and for bring light to such a dark time in our lives at the time.

At the time I got the MRI we were given the same news we already knew followed by some not helpful comments such us ‘our baby’s head was in disproportion to the rest of the body’, which I disputed and wasn’t accurate, but it was heartbreaking as we were, once again, told that our baby won’t reach a nice future, won’t be able to live by itself, work or even walk.

At that time we knew already that this condition was also known as the ‘snowflake condition’ and also, thanks to my medical background I knew there wasn’t any evidence behind those comments, but this didn’t make it less hurtful.

When all the results were back, we had another appointment at Jessops with Professor Anumba who was absolutely incredible, showed us lots of patience and resolved our thousand million doubts.

We asked to be referred to UCLH for a consultation regarding the prenatal surgery as at this point we were sure we were meeting their criteria. But he also referred us for another consultation just in case this wasn’t successful, so we had all our options covered. He was incredible and really supportive.

After a long week, of waiting (this was already September), we got a call from Emma, fellow researcher and doctor who was extremely sympathetic and supportive during the whole of our journey with the team. She confirmed that everything was looking right but have to send our details to Professor Jan Deprest to confirm all.

Shortly after we discovered, again thanks to Elouise’ mum, a group on Facebook that has been our anchor and saviour along this journey, lots of parents who have endured this same journey as us before. Everybody has been extremely helpful and supportive and they even meet from time to time with their babies and celebrate their tiny warriors milestones!

We were much positive at that time, because initially we fell alone and like this was some kind of punishment and also wondering: why us? We did everything by the book, folic acid tablets previous to pregnancy and up to 14 weeks (instead 12)... it has been a really tough journey with lots of bumps and ups and downs during the way.

We had our surgery last 27th of October in Belgium. I don’t have words to praise the work that Professor Jan Deprest and his team do for these kids. There are no words to say how thankful we are that our baby got this opportunitty and the massive difference it will (and already is) make to its life..

And also, we are so thankful for everybody back in Leuven (doctors, anaesthetic team, midwives, student midwives, cleaners, waitresses... the list goes on) but also so thankful to the NHS for give us this opportunity and funding our baby’s surgery.

 Any donations towards Great Ormond Street Children’s Charity would be greatly appreciated from the both of us as the only way this surgery can be offered on the NHS is if they can rely on donations from the public towards this charity. Any shares of our story are also greatly appreciated to raise awareness of this surgery as many people don’t know this 3rd choice exists. Thank You.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page. I would really appreciate if you were able to make even a small sum of donation. This can help keep up the good work that Cancer charities do. 

Cancer is a subject which is close to my heart - I have had the most important person in my life affected by it and taken from me.

Besides doing race for life a few years ago, I have always wanted to do more for Cancer charities. The first thing I have decided to do is donate 15 inches of my 29 inch hair. As soon as lockdown is over I will be going to the hairdresser to do this. The hair will be donated through a Charity (Little Princess Trust) for children who have been affected by cancer and are going through hair loss - donating my hair will allow a wig to be made for a child.

My Mum’s Story - My mum battled with cancer 3 times. In November 2016 we were told my mum had a tumour. After undergoing major surgery in January 2017, my mum was diagnosed with stage 4 aggressive ovarian cancer. Shortly after this, my mum started chemotherapy. She went through many physical changes including hair loss but the treatment was successful. However, soon after this her tumour markers began to increase - the cancer was active and was growing. She had a second round of chemotherapy and again this was successful in stopping the spread of the cancer. 

Just before the COVID-19 pandemic, my mums tumour markers began to increase. A few months later the cancer was back and growing faster than ever. The doctors advised for her to be on chemo tablets before undergoing another cycle of chemotherapy. After being on tablets for a short while, her scans showed an increase in the spread. However at this time, unfortunately we had gone into lockdown due to the pandemic. Because of this my mums appointments and treatments got delayed. She of course had to shield and didn't go out for several months until she was advised too. 

There was supposed to be many memorable moments including my sisters wedding - this was meant to be in May but was cancelled due to the lockdown. When my mum finally went for a scan the results were not good. She started her third round of chemotherapy and after one treatment my mum was not in good health. She kept getting infections which delayed her next treatment. As she got rid of those infections, she had a second treatment and once again fell sick - this delayed her chemotherapy for another few weeks when it was meant to be administered on a weekly basis. The changes in her appearance were striking and she got worse every day.  

In mid-October, we were told her treatment was not working and it would not be carried on. This meant there was no other options for us and no one could really be sure of how fast the cancer would spread and how much time we would have left with her. To fulfil one of her dreams, my sister got married in the last week of October. My mum soldiered on to be as fit as she could be for this and happily saw out all of the wedding events. However, within a week her health changed rapidly - she needed equipment to help aid her throughout her day and routine. She deteriorated quicker then anyone could imagine. We had to be her 24 hour carers throughout the day and night. This feeling is unexplainable and it is very hard to see the person you love most being in so much pain. Sadly on 9th November my beloved mother passed away in the early hours of the morning. She waited to see all her siblings and shortly left us that night with all of her family by her side.

We can’t believe this has happened to such a kind and beautiful soul. We are all still in shock that our mum has been taken from us and she had to struggle in the last 3 years of her life - at such a young age. She was a strong lady who impacted everyone positively in her life. My mum was the light of our lives, she kept everyone together, she was brave, she was strong and she fought so hard till the very end. Her suffering has ended and now she is able to rest in peace. She brought our family up on good morals, values and made us strong - even when she was unwell. 


I didn't have the chance to tell my mum I would be doing this for her as she was taken so fast from us. Donating my hair and raising money is my tribute to my mum and will help me carry on her legacy. I hope our angel is watching over us.
Rest peacefully mum. We will meet again one day 🥀

I know times are tough & made me realise how tough it must be for charities & their selflessness, they still have to operate.

So no matter how big or small if you can, it would be greatly appreciated to sponsor my no smoking journey as promised to Angela, aswell as her birthday gift alternative, even just to donate the price of a vodka & diet coke that you would have bought her out for her birthday 😍

Each week what I would normally spend on cigarettes I'll be adding to the fundraiser & will do so until I close it 😊

story: The Marie Curie Bradford Hospice supports people living with a terminal illness. In Alan's case that was to take care of him as an in-patient for six weeks, the goal being to work out how to manage his acute pain.  The staff were working continually to do this throughout that time. Once stabilised this then enabled him to return home for the last four months of his life. Due to the Covid-19 epidemic the hospice, despite tight restrictions, endeavoured to make the hospice is as comfortable as possible for patients and visitors. Alan particularly enjoyed the home-cooked food. The make every effort to treat each person as an individual and help them to reach their goals and fulfil their wishes, which was to be as pain free as possible and return to his own home. A team of nurses, doctors, social workers, physiotherapists, chaplains, bereavement counsellors and pharmacists work together, putting every person at the centre of their care. Throughout Covid-19 Bradford Hospice teams have been working around the clock to continue supporting local people. Death, dying and bereavement is at the forefront of peoples minds and Marie Curie knows what a difference the right care at the end of life can make. They cant do any of this without your support. Alan really appreciated all their help and it was important for him that this should be recognised. Thank you for any donation you are able to give to support the Bradford Hospice and Marie Curie care.

story:
We are the Youghal Fundraising Branch, we run several events throughout the year including, coffee mornings, our flag day, and we also hold collections in the Aldi store in Youghal for our national fundraiser Mayday. The annual Ardmore Christmas swim is also run in aid of Youghal RNLI. We have many supporters in our community and are very grateful of their ongoing support. We hope to raise much needed funds for the lifeboat to continue its lifesaving work. 

Our RNLI lifeboats in Ireland protect hundreds of communities through our 24-hour search and rescue service. They rely on the safest, most reliable lifeboats and modern stations to launch from. Ireland's unrivalled coasts and inland waters are valued by local communities and visitors alike. But the water remains an unpredictable environment that can catch people out. People will always need our help and we will always be there to answer that call.

The Youghal Lifeboat station is situated in the south east of Cork, Youghal has had a lifeboat station for nearly 180 years, and the crews have been awarded six RNLI medals for gallantry. Today’s station operates an inshore B class Atlantic 85 lifeboat.  Keeping our
Youghal lifeboat maintained, fuelled and ever ready to go to the rescue is expensive and we rely entirely on voluntary donations to ensure this service is maintained. Add to that crew training and kit, and the euros start to add up. During the pandemic we have still been offering a lifesaving service and are continuing to raise vital funds. However, we haven’t been able to take part in our traditional fundraising this year and rely on donations from the public to continue saving lives. Your donation will help support the run the Youghal lifeboat.

charity.name: Cool Earth
eventName: NUSU RAG The Peaks of the Balkans Trek 2021
story:
Cool Earth is the charity that works alongside rainforest communities to prevent deforestation and its impact on climate change.

Cool Earth helps local communities build sustainable livelihoods to improve their incomes, empowering them to protect and conserve their trees and the multitude of wildlife living within them. It believes that healthier and more financially resilient communities will put less pressure on the biologically diverse ecosystems they live in.  Pulling people out of poverty leads to strong communities and strong forests.

Cool Earth is proud to partner with NUSU RAG and Endeavours Adventures for the Peaks of the Balkans challenge event.

story: Challenge yourself to drink nothing but water this January. Take on the ultimate detox by avoiding caffeine, alcohol and all other drinks while supporting WaterAid. Go 100% pure and give the gift of clean water. Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in communities across Ethiopia. Together, we will bring clean water to 50,000 people in Ethiopia and thousands more around the world, helping them change their own lives, forever. If you would like further information about the difference your gift will make and the positive impact it will have on peoples lives, please visit us at www.wateraid.org/uk
